questions.text: A patient has sensory loss just below the circumferential level of the umbilicus. This corresponds to a lesion at which spinal cord segment?
questions.solution:
The sensory loss just below the circumferential level of the umbilicus corresponds to the lesion at the T10 spinal cord segment. It indicates the involvement of the cord adjacent to T7-T8 vertebral bodies.

The spinal cord has 31 segments, but they do not always correspond to the same vertebral body.

The first seven pairs of cervical spinal nerves exit above the same-numbered vertebral bodies. All the subsequent nerves exit below the same-numbered vertebral bodies. This is because of the presence of eight cervical spinal cord segments but only seven cervical vertebrae.

The lower spinal nerves take an increasingly downward course to exit via intervertebral foramina.

questions.text: A patient presents with quadriplegia and difficulty in breathing. This presentation can be seen in spinal cord lesions at what level?
questions.solution:
Quadriplegia and weakness of the diaphragm (manifesting as difficulty in breathing) are associated with spinal cord lesion at the level of C1-C4 spinal segments. 

Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve arising from C3 - C5. 

The uppermost level of weakness and reflex loss with lesions:

  • At C5-C6 : Biceps
  • At C7: Finger, wrist extensors, and triceps
  • At C8 : Finger and wrist flexion

Note: Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and facial hypohidrosis) may accompany a cervical cord lesion at any level.

questions.text: Beevor’s sign is noted in a patient who has spinal cord injury. At what level is the injury likely to be?
questions.solution:
The Beevor’s sign localizes the spinal cord injury at T10-T12. 

Beevor’s sign is the abnormal upward movement of the umbilicus on abdominal wall contraction in the supine position. This is because a lesion in the T10-T12 level of the spinal cord paralyzes the lower abdominal muscles but the upper abdominal muscles are normally resulting in the upward movement of the umbilicus.

questions.text: A patient has a spinal cord lesion at the level of L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots. All of the following may be seen in this patient, except:

choices.text: Paralysis of hip flexion and adduction

questions.solution:
Lesions at L2 – L4 spinal nerve roots do not cause paralysis of the knee flexors.

The paralysis of the flexion at the knee occurs due to the lesion at L5 – S1.

questions.text:
Which of the following features would you expect to see in a patient with conus medullaris syndrome?
  1. Bilateral saddle anesthesia
  2. Bladder and bowel dysfunction
  3. Normal sexual function
  4. Absence of anal reflex
  5. Absence of patellar reflex
questions.solution:
The clinical features of the conus medullaris syndrome include:

  • Bilateral saddle anesthesia
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction
  • Impotence
  • Absence of bulbocavernosus (S2-S4) and anal reflexes (S4-S5)

The conus medullaris is the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord, comprising all the sacral and single coccygeal segments. Damage at this level of the cord, often occurs due to injuries to the lumbar vertebra, result in conus medullaris syndrome. Muscle strength is largely preserved in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will you suspect in a patient who has bladder dysfunction early in the progression of the disease?
questions.solution:
Early loss of bladder control is a feature of the conus medullaris syndrome.

It is characterized by urinary retention and atonic anal sphincter, which cause overflow urinary incontinence and fecal incontinence, respectively.

Option A: In the cauda equina syndrome, there is relative sparing of bladder control.

Options C and D: Bladder dysfunction is uncommon in Guillian–Barre syndrome and ALS.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with sudden onset difficulty in micturition and defaecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of cauda equina syndrome (CES).

CES signifies an injury of multiple lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal distal to the termination of the spinal cord at L1-L2. It is commonly due to a ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disk, lumbosacral spine fracture, hematoma within the spinal canal, compressive tumor, or other mass lesions.

Low back pain, weakness, and areflexia in the legs, saddle anesthesia, or loss of bladder function may occur. 

Treatment options include surgical decompression, sometimes urgently in an attempt to restore or preserve motor or sphincter function, or radiotherapy for metastatic tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following features will help you differentiate conus medullaris syndrome from cauda equina syndrome?
questions.solution:
Symmetric weakness of lower limbs helps in a diagnosis of conus medullaris syndrome.

There is an asymmetric motor loss in cauda equina syndrome.

Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.

Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome (also known as the hemicord syndrome). Knife or bullet injuries and demyelination are the most common causes of this condition.

Clinical features include:

  • Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) 
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Brown–Sequard syndrome with a lesion on the right side. Which of the following sensations on the right side will be affected?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is the type of sensation lost on the same side (ipsilateral) in Brown–Sequard syndrome. This is due to a lesion of the posterior column.

The sensations of crude touch, pain and temperature are lost on the opposite side, due to the lesions of anterior column or spinothalamic tract.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after he was hit by a plastic pipe on the back by a bully. On examination, the patient was found to have marked upper extremity weakness compared to the lower extremities. He also had a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk. Other sensations were intact in this region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome. 

This condition affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness > leg weakness. A dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

Option A: In Brown–Sequard Syndrome, ipsilateral weakness and loss of joint position and vibratory sense, with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense, one or two levels below the lesion is seen.

Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome is caused due to an ASA infarct. It typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.

Option D: In foramen magnum syndrome, compressive lesions near the foramen magnum may produce weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. This is referred to as 'around the clock' pattern.

questions.text: The MRI spine of a patient is shown below. What is the characteristic deficit seen in this condition?

choices.text: Around the clock pattern of weakness

questions.solution:
The MRI shows a syrinx located at C6–C7 in the cervical spine which is suggestive of syringomyelia. Suspended distribution of sensory deficit is a feature of this condition.

Syringomyelia is a developmental cavity of the cervical cord that may enlarge and produce progressive myelopathy or may remain asymptomatic.

It presents as a central cord syndrome with unilateral sensory loss in the hands initially. There is a loss of pain and temperature sensation with the sparing of touch and vibration. The sensory deficit has a distribution that is 'suspended' over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands. Areflexic weakness is seen in the upper limbs.

Extension of the syrinx into the grey matter of the cord causes muscle wasting in the lower neck, shoulders, arms, and hands with asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms. Extension of the syrinx into the medulla (syringobulbia) causes palatal or vocal cord paralysis, dysarthria, horizontal or vertical nystagmus, episodic dizziness or vertigo, and tongue weakness with atrophy.

questions.text: A patient presents with quadriparesis. He says that it started in his left arm, then progressed to the left leg, and then later to the right leg and arm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of an 'around-the-clock' pattern of weakness, which is seen in foramen magnum syndrome. 

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm. The weakness may begin in any of the limbs.

The lesions in the foramen magnum area interrupt decussating pyramidal tract fibers destined for the legs, resulting in weakness of the legs. There is typically suboccipital pain spreading to the neck and shoulders in foramen magnum syndrome.

questions.text: Anterior spinal artery thrombosis is characterized by all of the following, except:

choices.text: Loss of power in the lower limbs

questions.solution:
Anterior spinal artery thrombosis does not lead to loss of vibration sense. Vibration sense is carried by the posterior column.

Anterior spinal artery syndrome or anterior cord syndrome is the result of occlusion or diminished flow in the anterior spinal artery. There is bilateral tissue destruction at several contiguous levels that spares the posterior columns.

All spinal cord functions (motor, sensory, and autonomic) are lost below the level of the lesion, except vibration and position sensation.

questions.text: A patient with neurofibromatosis 1 is found to have multiple tumors above the level of the lumbar spine. Which of the following is an early feature of dysautonomia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The early feature of dysautonomia that can occur in this patient is spastic bladder. 

Dysautonomia due to brain and spinal cord disease above the level of the lumbar spine results first in increased urinary frequency and small bladder volume. Eventually, incontinence occurs. These features are suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion, i.e., spastic bladder.

On the other hand, dysautonomia due to peripheral nervous system (PNS) disease of autonomic nerve fibers results in large bladder volumes, increased urinary frequency, and overflow incontinence. These are features suggestive of a lower motor neuron lesion, i.e., flaccid bladder.

Postvoidal residual volume helps to distinguish between upper and lower motor neuron bladder dysfunction in the early stages of dysautonomia.

questions.text: Which of the following autonomic disorders do not involve the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Syringobulbia is a condition that affects the brainstem, not the spinal cord. It is a neurological disorder characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) which affects the brainstem (medulla).

The following autonomic disorders are associated with spinal cord involvement:

  • Syringomyelia
  • Multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)
  • Traumatic quadriplegia
  • Subacute combined degeneration
  • Tetanus
  • Stiff-person syndrome
  • Spinal cord tumors

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with an extramedullary tumor in the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Sacral sparing is not a feature of extramedullary tumors, it is seen in intramedullary tumors. Differences between extramedullary and intramedullary syndromes are:

Extramedullary Intramedullary
Radicular pain Poorly localized burning pain
Early sacral sensory loss Sacral sparing
Incontinence due to the superficial location of the corresponding sensory and motor fibers in the spinothalamic and corticospinal tracts Corticospinal tract signs appear later

Extramedullary tumors lie outside the cord and compress the spinal cord or its vascular supply. Intramedullary tumors arise within the substance of the cord.

The spinothalamic tract has a laminated configuration with the sacral fibers outermost, and hence, there is an early sacral sensory loss in extramedullary tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of subacute combined degeneration?
questions.solution:
Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. High consumption of refined rice leads to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels.

Clinical features include: 

  • Signs of both peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement
  • Paresthesias in the hands or feet > Weakness and unsteadiness of gait 
  • Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs
  • Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations

SACD is treated by a replacement regimen of intramuscular daily injections of 1000 μg of vitamin B12 for the first week, followed by weekly 1000 μg injections for 1 month, and monthly injections thereafter.
